Jim Miller is a San Diego printer whose life was changed in 1988 by a head-on car wreck he and his wife built it into the front seats to their Ford Escort had broken bones but they're twins 7 year old sons in the backseat wearing lap belts were severely injured one died and the other was rendered a paraplegic Miller was surprised to learn that earlier similar accidents have resulted in similar injuries but that Ford had not improved the seat belts

he says he found that Ford knew as early as 1967 about the vulnerability of backseat Riders wearing lap belts Miller blames secret out-of-court settlements in consumer lawsuits and now he's campaigning against them later we'll hear from attorneys on both sides of the question but now Jim Miller will join us from Los Angeles first humor you tell us what happened in the accident

well it was just taking the family out for a drive on a quiet Sunday afternoon as usual we're all belted up because we're pretty safety-conscious family and we always wanted to do what we were advised to do about a mile into our journey though a car crossed the center line and hit our vehicle head-on my wife and I and lap and shoulder belts in the front seat only broke bones I broke an ankle my wife worst injury was a broken collarbone and this as you can imagine was where the brunt of the impact occurred

the rear of the car though was completely intact it wasn't deformed in any way and yet our twin Sons Richard and James suffered devastating injuries by but what happened to them well both boys suffered major abdominal injuries both boys broke their spines and James also suffered a cervical injury and he died at it as a result now with a the lap belts didn't hold them in what was the defect know the lot Bells held them in the problem with lot belts is when there's a lack of a shoulder harness

often to prevent the upper body from from jackknifing forwards and that was definitely where James got his neck injury but at the same time the full force of the impact is concentrated on the midsection and that's what caused a devastating injury is there in fact Richards injuries are so bad that are even now on the left side of his body all the muscles in his lower abdomen were removed and what is the explanation for no shoulder harnesses in the back seats well I suppose her official a National Highway

a traffic safety administration and he told me that with their meager resources they had to concentrate on improving safety for the seats that were occupied he said not too many people sit in the back seats and so we've not really concentrated our efforts there okay so there's no doubt in your mind that if it were a choir that they'll be shoulder harnesses everywhere your kids would be okay and a lot more people would be alive absolutely I mean you don't have to look at the injuries my wife and I receive and the injuries my boys received and the answer is right there okay now what happened in the

suit well the first thing happen in a lawsuit a couple of documents turned up early and Discovery and one of these was dated 1967 and it was from the head of Ford's biomechanical engineering department to his superiors and it was the results of their study they done on the feasibility of lap and shoulder belt as opposed to lap only belt he concluded this memo by saying there was no question a lap and shoulder belt provided far more

safely than lap belt alone but for didn't pay attention to the memo they paid no attention at all and in fact in 1971 72 they did some more extensive tests with Crash Test Dummies that concluded that a person in a rear seat wearing a lap belt in an impact of thirty six to forty five miles an hour only had a two percent chance of survival compared to 98% chance had that person been wearing a lap and shoulder harness Bella would it cost to put a shoulder harness in the back well in
